title: Induced emf - circular loop in changing B-field

content.question: A circular loop of wire with a diameter of <math alttext="1.0 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> rests in a magnetic field directed into the page, perpendicular to the face of the loop, as shown. The magnetic field uniformly decreases from <math alttext="2.0 T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math> to <math alttext="0.5 T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math> over a time interval of <math alttext="5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>. Which of the following is most nearly equal to the magnitude of the induced <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>emf</mtext></math> in the loop during the time interval described?

choices.label: <math alttext="0.24 volt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.24</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math>
<math alttext="0.39 volt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.39</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math>
<math alttext="0.94 volt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.94</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math>
<math alttext="1.6 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="0.24 volt" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.24</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></math>
